description.narrative: With GGF funds, Fraser Riverkeeper Society (FRK) will promote its Lifting the Label initiative to inform and educate key institutions, including ten major US restaurant and seafood suppliers and targeted consumer groups, about the ecological harm and destruction caused by the British Columbia farmed salmon industry. FRK will encourage these institutions and salmon consumers to avoid buying net pen farmed Atlantic Salmon in favor of other seafood choices. In the past two years, the Global Aquaculture Alliance has produced industry created certification for Best Aquaculture Practices (BAP). This certification fails to set standards for the industry's use of parasiticides, antibiotics, its impacts on sea and river bottoms, or the dissemination of disease causing pathogens into the marine environment. This industry generated rubber stamp, created to give consumers the impression that salmon farms have been ecologically evaluated, is accepted standard for suppliers. FRK will work to show the true nature of the BAP certification and the harms of net pen salmon farming to the environment and consumers alike through the following activities: to engage US seafood suppliers and encourage them to discontinue the purchase of British Columbia net pen salmon; to reach US salmon consumers with web based salmon recipes and to encourage them to buy wild salmon; and to encourage the Aquarium of the Pacific to reconsider its partnership with British Columbia net pen salmon farming corporations and to stop promoting farmed salmon to consumers.
